The question asks for the number of female respondents in wave III who never listened to the radio in the past six months. To answer this, we need to refer to the data provided in image1, which details the frequency of radio listening among respondents.

![Radio Listening Habits](image1)

From image1, we can see that 55.7% of females never listened to the radio in the past six months. The sample size for wave III is 4,021 individuals, as indicated in image7. Therefore, the number of female respondents who never listened to the radio in the past six months can be calculated as follows:

Number of female respondents = 55.7% of 4,021 = 0.557 * 4,021 = 2,239.7

Since we cannot have a fraction of a person, we round this number to the nearest whole number, which gives us 2,240 female respondents who never listened to the radio in the past six months.

In contrast, in 2016, text quote [1] shows that only about a quarter (26%) of Trump voters say the president-elect should appoint Democrats to serve in his administration. This indicates a stark difference in the opinions of Trump voters in 2016 compared to Obama voters in 2008.

![{Percentage of voters who think Trump should appoint Democrats}](image1)

The difference in opinions reflects the varying political climates and the different contexts in which these appointments were considered. In 2008, there was a more balanced view among Obama's supporters regarding the appointment of Republicans, whereas in 2016, Trump's base showed a more divided opinion, with a significant portion believing that appointing Democrats was not necessary or even undesirable.

Americans generally express more worry than enthusiasm about the concept of machines performing jobs currently done by humans. According to the text, "More Americans are worried than enthusiastic about the notion that machines might do many of the jobs currently done by humans. Just 33% [5]... express enthusiasm." This is further supported by the image, which shows a bar graph depicting survey results where "Possible Negative Outcomes" are more likely than "Possible Positive Outcomes" [image1].

![Possible Negative and Positive Outcomes](image1)

Additionally, the image also illustrates public opinion on policies related to automation, showing that a majority of Democrats/lean Dem support the idea of machines doing dangerous or unhealthy jobs only, while Republicans/lean Rep show less support [image2]. 

![Policy Support for Automation](image2)

The perception of the concept's realism varies with awareness levels. Those who have heard a lot about the concept find it more realistic, with 48% finding it extremely realistic [image6]. However, even among those who have not heard much about it, a significant majority still find the concept realistic [text3].

![Awareness and Realism of Concept](image6)

Overall, the data indicates a mixed but generally cautious view towards the prospect of machines performing human jobs, with a notable emphasis on potential negative outcomes and a preference for policies that limit automation's impact on jobs [image1, image2, image3].

[1] Nearly six-in-ten Americans (58%) feel there should be limits on how many jobs businesses can replace with machines, while 41% believe businesses are justified in replacing humans with machines if they can receive better work at lower cost. [6] Fully 85% of Americans favor the idea that robots and computers be mostly limited to doing jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans. ![Limiting machines to dangerous jobs](image1) [9] Public is strongly supportive of limiting robots and computers to “dangerous and dirty” jobs, responds favorably to policy solutions such as a universal basic income or national service program for displaced workers. [7] A notably larger share of the public sides with the notion that there should be limits on the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines, as opposed to the idea that businesses are justified in replacing humans with machines. [4] In the event that robots and computers become capable of doing many human jobs, for example, 85% of Americans are in favor of limiting machines to performing primarily those jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans. [10] They strongly favor the notion that machines might be limited to jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans, and they offer somewhat more measured support for other types of interventions to limit the impact of widespread automation, such as the enactment of a universal basic income or national service program for displaced workers. [12] There are no major partisan differences in support for limiting machines to dangerous and dirty jobs, or for giving people the option to pay extra to interact with a human rather than a robot in commercial transactions. [5] Just over half of Republicans (54%) feel that there should be limits to how many human jobs businesses can replace with machines, only slightly less than the 60% of Democrats who hold this view. [7] Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are substantially more likely than Republicans and Republican-leaning independents to favor both a universal income (by a 77% to 38% margin) and a national service program (by a 66% to 46% margin) in the event that machines threaten to displace substantial numbers of human workers. [12] Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are much more supportive than Republicans and Republican-leaning independents of both a universal basic income (77% of Democrats favor this idea, compared with just 38% of Republicans) as well as a national service program (66% vs. 46%). [10] And although they view certain jobs as being more at risk than others, a significant majority of today’s workers express little concern that their own jobs or careers might be performed by machines in their lifetimes.

According to the Pew Research Center, the major reasons for the underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM jobs include limited access to quality education, discrimination in recruitment and promotions, and a lack of encouragement to pursue STEM from an early age. These factors are cited by a significant portion of the population, with specific percentages indicating their prevalence. For instance, $39\%$ of Americans consider a lack of encouragement for girls and blacks and Hispanics to pursue STEM from an early age as a major reason there are not more women in some STEM areas, and $41\%$ say this is a major reason there are not more blacks and Hispanics in the STEM workforce [1]. Additionally, $62\%$ of blacks in STEM say they have experienced discrimination at work because of their race or ethnicity, compared with $44\%$ of Asians, $42\%$ of Hispanics, and just $13\%$ of whites in STEM jobs [2]. 

![Women and men in STEM value different characteristics](image1)

Furthermore, $72\%$ of blacks say a major reason why blacks and Hispanics are underrepresented in these jobs is because they face discrimination in recruiting, hiring and promotions; by contrast only around a quarter of whites $(27\%)$ and Asians $(28\%)$ say this [4]. Most blacks in STEM positions consider major underlying reasons for the under representation of blacks and Hispanics in science, technology, engineering and math occupations to be limited access to quality education, discrimination in recruitment and promotions and a lack of encouragement to pursue these jobs from an early age [5]. 

![Perceptions of education quality](image2)

The Pew Research Center also highlights that people who are employed in a STEM job are more likely than those working in non-STEM jobs to cite lack of access to quality education, lack of encouragement to pursue subjects at an early age, and lack of black and Hispanic role models working in the field as major reasons why these groups are underrepresented in STEM jobs [8]. 

![Major reasons for underrepresentation in STEM](image5)

Most Americans rate K-12 STEM education as average or worse compared with other developed nations, so, too, do those with an advanced degree in STEM [1]. ![Americans are generally critical of the quality of STEM education in the nation’s K-12 schools. A quarter of Americans (25%) consider K-12 STEM education in the U.S. to be at least above average compared with other developed countries, while 30% say the U.S. is below average in this regard, and 43% say it is average.](image10)  
[9] However, a significant portion of STEM postgraduate degree holders also view K-12 STEM education negatively. Fewer than half of the public consider STEM education in the U.S. to be at least above average when compared with other developed nations [2]. ![% of U.S. adults in each group who rate each level of science, technology, engineering and math education in the U.S. as the best in the world or above average](image7)  
[7] In contrast, just 13% of those with a STEM postgraduate degree rate K-12 STEM education as above average and about half (51%) say the U.S. is below average in this regard [11]. ![The image is a bar chart that illustrates the major reasons why more women, blacks, and Hispanics are not in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) jobs.](image2)  
[2] This disparity highlights that while the general public may have a more nuanced view, STEM professionals tend to have a more critical perspective on the quality of K-12 STEM education.

The document evaluates levels of confidence and likelihood through a combination of expert judgment, evidence quality, and consensus among authors. Confidence in the validity of findings is based on the type, amount, quality, strength, and consistency of evidence, as well as the degree of expert agreement. Confidence is expressed qualitatively, ranging from low confidence (inconclusive evidence or disagreement among experts) to very high confidence (strong evidence and high consensus) [9]. 

![Confidence Levels](image8)  
This image illustrates the different levels of confidence, from "Very High" to "Low," based on the strength and reliability of evidence.

Likelihood, on the other hand, describes the probability of an impact occurring and is quantitatively assessed. It ranges from very unlikely (less than or equal to a 1 in 10 chance) to very likely (greater than or equal to a 9 in 10 chance) [3]. 

![Probability Terms](image4)  
This image provides a visual representation of probability terms and their corresponding numerical ranges, helping to convey the likelihood of events based on subjective assessments.

Each Key Finding is accompanied by a Traceable Account that documents the process and rationale used by the authors to reach their conclusions, providing additional information on sources of uncertainty [5]. The evaluation of confidence and likelihood levels is determined by assessing the available literature, determining the quality and quantity of evidence, and evaluating the level of agreement across different studies [11].

The public's perceptions of political parties' ethics and extremism vary significantly among different educational and political affiliation groups, as indicated by several quotes and images. 

![Both parties have high ethical standards](image1) According to image1, the Democratic Party is slightly more favored for having high ethical standards than the Republican Party, with 42% versus 41%. However, this view is not uniform across all groups. For instance, independents are more likely to say neither party has high ethical standards, with 34% of independents holding this view, as noted in quote [5]. 

![Political party preference among various demographic groups](image2) Image2 shows that political party preference varies widely among different demographic groups, but it does not directly address ethical standards or extremism. However, it does highlight that there are significant differences in support for Democratic and Republican parties across various demographics.

![Opinions about the traits of the two parties continue to be deeply divided along partisan lines](image3) Quote [11] states that opinions about the traits of the two parties continue to be deeply divided along partisan lines. This is further supported by image3, which compares opinions among Republicans and Democrats in May 2018 and August 2017. It shows that among Republicans, the distribution of opinions changed from 30% and 69% in August 2017 to 19% and 80% in May 2018, indicating a shift in perceptions.

![How different groups perceive the political parties](image4) Image4 provides a detailed breakdown of how different groups perceive the political parties. It shows that the percentage of people who think both parties are described by certain attributes, think one party is described by certain attributes, and think neither party is described by certain attributes varies by education level and political affiliation.

![How closely different demographic groups follow an unspecified subject](image6) Image6 indicates that different demographic groups follow an unspecified subject to varying degrees. While this does not directly address ethical standards or extremism, it does show that there are differences in how closely different groups follow certain subjects, which could be related to their perceptions of political parties.

In summary, perceptions of political parties' ethics and extremism differ among various educational and political affiliation groups, with independents being more likely to view neither party as having high ethical standards and partisans generally having more positive views of their own party.

The perception of ethical standards and extremism between the Republican and Democratic parties reveals significant differences, as highlighted in the text and image quotes. According to the text, **41%** of Americans say the GOP has high ethical standards, while **42%** say this about the Democratic Party, indicating a slight edge for the Democrats in this regard [4]. However, **48%** of Americans view the Republican Party as "too extreme," compared to **42%** for the Democratic Party [7], suggesting a stronger perception of extremism among Republicans.

These views are also influenced by education and political affiliation. Among those with at least a college degree, **31%** say “high ethical standards” does not describe either party, while **43%** believe it applies to one but not the other [3]. In contrast, fewer of those with some college experience (**26%**) or a high school degree or less (**20%**) think neither party has high ethical standards [12], indicating that higher education levels may lead to more nuanced or critical views of political parties.

Political affiliation also plays a role. Partisans are somewhat less positive about their own party in terms of ethical standards, though majorities of Republicans (**66%**) and Democrats (**64%**) describe their party this way [8]. Independents are significantly more likely than partisans to say neither party has high ethical standards, with **34%** of independents expressing this view, compared to only about **19%** of Republicans or **18%** of Democrats [5].

The bar chart (image1) further supports these findings, showing that both parties are rated equally at **50%** for having good policy ideas, while the Democratic Party is slightly higher at **42%** for having high ethical standards compared to the Republican Party at **41%**. The same image also shows that the Republican Party is rated higher at **48%** for being "too extreme" compared to the Democratic Party at **42%**.

In summary, perceptions of ethical standards and extremism differ between the Republican and Democratic parties, with Republicans generally viewed as more extreme and Democrats slightly more ethically sound. These perceptions are influenced by education and political affiliation, with higher education levels and independent views leading to more critical assessments of both parties.

Public confidence in Trump's economic policy has shown some improvement, with 53% expressing at least some confidence in him to make good decisions about economic policy as of May 2018, up from 46% in January. This is reflected in the bar chart (image1), where the percentage for economic policy decisions increased from 46% to 53%. However, this does not mean that the public fully supports his economic policies, as there is still a significant portion of the population who do not have much confidence in him on this issue.

![Public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy](image1)

In terms of ethical standards, the situation is more complex. While 50% of the public views both the Republican and Democratic parties as having good policy ideas, there is a stark difference in how these parties are perceived regarding Trump's ethical standards. According to text quote [9], three-quarters of Republicans (75%) give the administration high marks, while 86% of Democrats rate its ethical standards negatively. This is also illustrated in image8, which shows that a large majority of Democrats (86%) consider the ethical standards of the Trump administration to be poor, while only a small fraction of Republicans (22%) do so.

![Ethical standards of the Trump administration](image8)

The image4 provides further insight into the differing opinions among political groups. It shows that Republicans are more likely to have mixed feelings about Trump's conduct, with 45% saying they have mixed feelings about the way he conducts himself as president. In contrast, Democrats are much more critical, with 85% saying they don't like the way Trump conducts himself in office.

![Opinions on Trump's conduct](image4)

In summary, while there is some improvement in public confidence in Trump's economic policy, there is a significant divide in how his ethical standards are viewed among different political groups. Republicans tend to be more supportive of his conduct, while Democrats are largely critical of it.

Since January, public confidence in Trump to handle an international crisis has increased from 35% to 43% [12], while confidence in his economic policy handling has risen from 46% to 53% [10]. These improvements are part of a broader trend where public confidence in Trump on several key issues has remained mixed, though a narrow majority (54%) now say they are either very or somewhat confident in him to negotiate favorable trade agreements with other countries [11]. 

![Handle an international crisis](image3)  
This image shows that public confidence in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis has declined from 48% in April 2017 to a low of 35%, then rises to 43% by May 2018. Similarly, confidence in his economic policy decisions has increased from 46% in January 2018 to 53% in May 2018 [3].

Partisan perspectives also reflect these changes. Eight-in-ten Republicans and Republican-leaners (80%) now say they agree with Trump on many or all issues, up 11 percentage points from last August [3]. However, Democrats continue to overwhelmingly say they do not like the way Trump conducts himself (85%), with only 10% expressing mixed feelings and 5% saying they like his behavior [8].

This image shows that among the total population, 54% don't like the way Trump conducts himself, while 19% like it and 26% have mixed feelings. For Republicans, 16% don't like him, 38% like him, and 45% have mixed feelings. For Democrats, 85% don't like him, 5% like him, and 10% have mixed feelings.

Overall, while public confidence in Trump's ability to handle economic policy and international crises has shown some improvement, partisan divides remain significant, with Republicans more supportive and Democrats more critical of his conduct.

The public's evaluation of Donald Trump's conduct as president has remained relatively stable over recent months, with little change since the beginning of his presidency [8]. The 2016 U.S. presidential election elicited a range of voter reactions that differed from previous elections, with notable emotional responses. According to the text quotes, half of voters were happy with Trump's victory, while nearly as many were unhappy, similar to reactions in 2012 but less positive than after Obama's first campaign in 2008. Overall, 73% of all voters expressed surprise at Trump's win, with 87% of Clinton voters and 60% of Trump voters also feeling surprised.

![Voter surprise](image8)  
This image shows the percentage of voters who were surprised or not surprised by Trump's victory, highlighting the widespread surprise among all voters.

Emotionally, voters had mixed reactions. 51% felt hopeful about Trump's election, while 36% felt proud. However, 53% felt uneasy, 41% sad, and 41% scared. These emotions are reflected in the chart below:

![Emotional reactions](image2)  
This image depicts the various emotions reported by voters, with the highest percentages indicating unease and sadness.

Comparing these emotions to those of previous elections, such as Obama's 2008 election, we see a shift in emotional responses. In 2008, voters were more positive, with 69% feeling hopeful and only 35% feeling uneasy. The 2016 election, however, was marked by more negative assessments of the campaign and a more divided emotional response.

![Emotional reactions comparison](image3)  
This image compares the emotional reactions of Trump and Clinton voters, showing that Trump voters predominantly felt hopeful and proud, while Clinton voters felt uneasy, sad, scared, and angry.

In terms of satisfaction with the election outcome, 97% of Trump voters were happy with his victory, while only 15% of Clinton voters were satisfied. This is a significant difference compared to 2008, where 92% of Obama voters were satisfied and 39% of McCain voters were satisfied.

![Satisfaction with election outcome](image4)  
This image compares the satisfaction levels of voters for winning and losing candidates in 2016 and 2008, highlighting the stark contrast in satisfaction levels between Trump and Clinton voters.

Overall, the 2016 election was characterized by a mix of emotions and a significant difference in satisfaction levels between voters of the two major parties. The most prevalent emotions were hopefulness and unease, with a notable level of surprise among all voters.

The emotional reactions to Trump's election differ significantly between Trump and Clinton voters. According to the data, **96% of Trump voters feel hopeful** while only **7% of Clinton voters feel hopeful** about Trump's election. Similarly, **74% of Trump voters feel proud**, whereas only **1% of Clinton voters feel proud**. On the other hand, **90% of Clinton voters feel uneasy**, **77% feel sad**, and **76% feel scared** about Trump's victory. In contrast, **13% of Trump voters feel uneasy**, **4% feel sad**, and **5% feel scared**. This is illustrated in the image ![Hopeful, Proud, Uneasy, Sad, Scared, Angry](image5). 

Regarding their expectations of Trump's first term, **97% of Trump voters expect him to have a successful first term**, which is comparable to **92% of Obama voters** in 2008. However, **only 15% of Clinton voters expect Trump's first term to be successful**, while **76% expect it to be unsuccessful**, as shown in the image ![Perceived Success of Trump 2016 vs Obama 2008](image7). 

These differences highlight the contrasting emotional responses and expectations between Trump and Clinton voters regarding Trump's election and his potential performance as president.

The perspectives about the potential success of Trump's first term and willingness to give him a chance differ significantly between Trump and Clinton voters. According to the text quotes, 97% of Trump voters expect him to have a successful first term, which is comparable to the 92% of Obama voters who said this about their candidate in 2008 [9]. In contrast, only 15% of Clinton supporters think Trump’s first term will be successful, while 76% think it will be unsuccessful [10]. 

![{Trump voters expect Trump to have a successful first term}](image7)

Regarding willingness to give Trump a chance, 58% of Clinton voters say they are “willing to give Trump a chance and see how he governs,” but nearly 39% say they can’t see themselves giving Trump a chance “because of the kind of person he has shown himself to be” [11]. On the other hand, the image shows that 96% of Trump voters feel hopeful about the kind of president he will be, while only 7% of Clinton voters feel hopeful [1]. 

![{Clinton voters feel more negative emotions towards Trump}](image1)

These differences highlight the polarized views among voters regarding Trump's potential success and their willingness to support him.

The priorities for Trump's presidency differ significantly between Trump and Clinton voters, reflecting their distinct views on his leadership. According to the text quotes, **29% of Trump voters** name health care as his first priority, compared with only **12% of Clinton voters** (quote [9]). Similarly, **15% of Trump voters** prioritize the economy, while **9% of Clinton voters** do so (quote [10]). Both groups also highlight immigration as a key issue, with **15% of Trump voters** versus **6% of Clinton voters** prioritizing it (quote [10]).

However, **Clinton voters** are more likely to prioritize **unifying the country** as Trump's first priority, with **12%** of them suggesting this (quote [6]), while **only 5% of Trump voters** mention it (quote [10]). This suggests that Clinton voters may view unification as a critical aspect of Trump's leadership, whereas Trump voters may focus more on immediate issues like health care and the economy.

The image quotes further support these differences. Image [5] shows that **Trump voters** are more likely to prioritize health care, the economy, and immigration, while **Clinton voters** are more likely to prioritize unifying the country and changing personal behavior (image [5]). Image [7] indicates that **Clinton voters** are more inclined to give greater priority to the leader's supporters, whereas **Trump voters** are more likely to give equal priority to all Americans (image [7]).

These differences suggest that Trump voters may view Trump's leadership through the lens of immediate economic and social issues, while Clinton voters may see leadership as a broader, more inclusive process aimed at unifying the country and addressing personal behavior. The differing priorities reflect the diverse views on what constitutes effective leadership and the role of a president in shaping the nation. 

![Health Care and Economy Priorities](image5)  
![Priority Giving to Supporters](image7)

These changes are reflected in their reactions to the 2016 election outcomes, highlighting a significant partisan divide.

In 2008, voters generally expected political leaders to work with newly elected presidents, as seen in the data from November 2008. For instance, nearly eight-in-ten $(78\%)$ of Obama’s voters said that Democratic leaders in Washington should work with Republicans even at the risk of disappointing their supporters, and a similar proportion of McCain’s voters $(76\%)$ said the same [6]. This contrasts with the 2016 election, where the graph shows a significant increase in the perception that there was more mudslinging or negative campaigning than in past elections, with $92\%$ of voters saying there was more "mudslinging" in 2016 compared to $72\%$ after the 2004 election [image1].

![{The graph shows an increasing trend in the perception that there is more mudslinging in recent elections.}](image1)

In 2016, the survey results indicate that among all voters, 59% believed Democratic leaders should work with Trump to get things done, while 39% felt they should stand up to him on important issues [8]. Among Republicans or those leaning Republican, 84% preferred working with Trump, while 14% preferred standing up to him. Among Democrats or those leaning Democratic, 32% supported working with Trump, and 65% supported standing up to him. This reflects a shift in voter expectations and sentiments towards political leaders working with or against newly elected presidents between 2008 and 2016.

The 2016 election was marked by widespread negative perceptions of political entities and campaign negativity, as indicated by multiple sources. According to text quote [4], most voters viewed the 2016 presidential campaign as one to forget, with post-election evaluations of the winning candidate, the parties, the press, and the pollsters being far more negative than after any election since 1988. This sentiment is further supported by text quote [12], which states that 92% of voters said there was more "mudslinging" or negative campaigning than in past elections, a significant increase from previous years.

The image1 provides visual evidence of this trend, showing a line graph that illustrates the percentage of voters who perceived more mudslinging in various election years. The graph indicates an increasing trend in the perception that there is more mudslinging in recent elections, with 92% of voters in 2016 perceiving more mudslinging compared to 72% in 2004. This aligns with text quote [2], which notes that about nine-in-ten voters said there was more mudslinging or negative campaigning compared with previous contests.

Additionally, text quote [3] highlights that voters gave abysmal grades to the press and pollsters, whose pre-election surveys were widely criticized. The image4 shows a table presenting survey data on public perception and grading of various entities related to the political context. According to the table, the press and pollsters received low grades, with the press receiving an average grade of D+ and the pollsters also receiving an average grade of D+. This supports the notion that voters had negative perceptions of these entities.

Furthermore, text quote [7] mentions that voters give abysmal grades to the press and pollsters, whose pre-election surveys were widely criticized. The image4 also supports this, showing that only 22% of voters gave the press a grade of an A or B, while 38% gave it a failing grade. Similarly, fewer voters awarded pollsters grades of A or B than a grade of F, with 30% giving pollsters a failing grade.

In conclusion, voter perceptions of political entities and campaign negativity in the 2016 election are closely related, with voters having negative perceptions of various entities including the press, pollsters, and political parties. The campaign was characterized by increased negativity, as evidenced by the high percentage of voters who perceived more mudslinging in the 2016 election. ![More mudslinging](image1)

The emotional reactions of Trump and Clinton voters following the 2016 election are quite distinct, reflecting their differing perspectives on the outcome. For Trump supporters, the most common reactions were "happy" and "surprised," with a significant majority feeling hopeful and proud about his election win [2][5]. In contrast, Clinton voters predominantly felt "shocked," "disappointed," and "disgusted," with a large percentage reporting feelings of unease, sadness, and fear [10][5].

![Clinton and Trump Voter Reactions](image2)

These emotional responses are closely tied to the overall perception of Trump's performance and the level of mudslinging during the election. The data indicates that voters viewed the 2016 campaign as exceptionally negative, with 92% believing there was more mudslinging than in previous elections [7]. This perception of negativity is further reflected in the emotional responses of voters, with a significant portion feeling uneasy or scared about Trump's victory [6][8].

![Public Perception of Mudslinging](image6)

The combination of these factors suggests that the emotional reactions of voters were heavily influenced by their views on Trump's performance and the overall tone of the election. Trump supporters were more likely to feel positive emotions, while Clinton supporters were more likely to feel negative emotions, which aligns with their perceptions of the election's conduct.

The emotional reactions to Trump's victory differ significantly between Trump and Clinton voters, reflecting their varying expectations prior to the election. For Trump supporters, "happy" is the most frequent response, indicating a sense of relief or satisfaction with the outcome, as many were not surprised by his win. This is supported by the image showing that 60% of Trump voters expressed surprise at the outcome, though 40% said they were not surprised he won [6]. In contrast, Clinton voters are more likely to feel "shocked" and "disappointed," as noted in the text where 87% of Clinton voters were surprised by Trump's victory [2]. 

![Clinton voters surprised](image6)  
This image shows that 87% of Clinton voters were surprised by Trump's victory, highlighting their unexpectedness of the result.

The difference in emotional reactions suggests that Trump voters had higher confidence in their vote count and were less surprised by the outcome, while Clinton voters were more disheartened by the result, indicating they may have had higher expectations for a different outcome [12]. 

The comparison of emotional reactions reveals that Trump voters were more optimistic about the election's outcome, whereas Clinton voters were more pessimistic, reflecting differing expectations and possibly varying levels of preparedness for the result.

The public perception of government efforts to combat terrorism has shifted significantly over time, as illustrated by the line graph in image1. From 2004 to 2015, there was a clear trend where concern that government policies did not go far enough to protect the country increased, while concern that they had gone too far in restricting civil liberties decreased. By 2015, 56% of Americans believed the government had not gone far enough, compared to 28% who thought it had gone too far.

![Government Anti-Terror Policies](image1)

These changes are also reflected in the political affiliations and age groups. According to text quote [7], both Republicans and Democrats have become more likely to say that the government’s anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough to protect the country since Snowden’s disclosures in 2013. However, the shift has been more pronounced among Republicans. Text quote [8] further notes that similar proportions of conservative Republicans, moderate and liberal Republicans, and conservative and moderate Democrats say their greater concern is that anti-terrorism policies have not gone far enough. In contrast, equal shares of liberal Democrats express concern that policies have gone too far in restricting civil liberties.

Age group differences are also evident. Text quote [6] indicates that older and less educated Americans are more likely to give the government low marks for the job it is doing reducing the threat of terrorism. Specifically, a majority of those 50 and older (57%) say the government is not doing well, while younger adults (18-29) have a more positive view, with 53% saying it is doing very or fairly well.

![Political Affiliation Trends](image2)

In summary, public perceptions of government efforts to combat terrorism have generally become more negative over time, with significant variations by political affiliation and age group. Older and less educated individuals, as well as certain political groups like Republicans, are more critical of the government's performance in this area.

The question of how age and political ideology influence perceptions of government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat, and how these perceptions have changed over time, is complex and multifaceted. According to the data, older and less educated Americans are more likely to give the government low marks for its efforts in combating terrorism, as noted in [11]. This aligns with [4], which shows that among those 50 and older, a majority (57%) say the government is not doing well reducing the terrorist threat, while younger adults (18-29) have a more positive view, with 53% saying the government is doing very or fairly well.

![Concerns over U.S. involvement in Iraq and Syria also differ by age](image1)

Political ideology also plays a significant role. [3] indicates that Democrats are the only partisan group where a majority (64%) say the government is doing at least fairly well in combating terrorism, down from 85% in January. Independents’ positive ratings have dropped significantly, from 69% to 44%, and Republicans' positive ratings have fallen from 63% to 27%. These changes suggest a shift in public opinion over time, with increasing skepticism towards government efforts across different political groups.

Over time, there has been a notable change in public perception. [2] states that by two-to-one, Americans now say they are more concerned that the government’s anti-terror policies have not gone far enough to protect the country (56%) rather than that these policies have gone too far in restricting civil liberties (28%). This reflects a growing concern about the balance between security and civil liberties.

![Evaluations of the government’s job reducing the threat of terrorism are more positive among and those with a postgraduate degree than among other educational groups](image6)

The data also shows that concerns over U.S. involvement in Iraq and Syria differ by age. Adults under the age of 30 express more concern about the U.S. going too far in getting involved in the situation (55%) than not going far enough to stop the Islamic militants (37%). In contrast, all older age groups are more concerned about the U.S. not doing enough to stop Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria than getting too involved in the situation [7].

These findings highlight that both age and political ideology significantly influence perceptions of government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat, with older and less educated individuals, as well as certain political groups, expressing more negative views. Over time, there has been a shift in public opinion, with increasing concerns about the effectiveness of government anti-terror policies and a growing emphasis on the balance between security and civil liberties.

The evolution of opinions on government anti-terrorism efforts among different age groups and political affiliations reflects a complex interplay of public sentiment and policy impacts. According to the data, adults under 30 are split between concerns that U.S. policies place too many restrictions on civil liberties (43%) and that they do not go far enough to protect the country (44%) [8]. In contrast, majorities in every other age group are more concerned about security than civil liberties, with this concern being more pronounced among those 65 and older (71%) than those 30-49 (52%) [8].

Looking at the table, the percentage of respondents who believe that civil liberties are being overly restricted varies by age group: 43% for ages 18-29, 32% for ages 30-49, 21% for ages 50-64, and 15% for ages 65+ [4]. Conversely, the percentage of respondents who feel that more measures are needed to protect the U.S. is higher among older age groups, with 71% of those 65+ feeling this way [4].

Political affiliations also play a role in these opinions. The table shows that both Republicans and Democrats have become more likely to say that the government’s anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough to protect the country since Snowden’s disclosures in 2013. However, the shift has been more pronounced among Republicans. Slightly more than seven-in-ten Republicans (71%) now say their greater concern is that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough, up 14 points since January (57%) and 33 points since July 2013 (38%) [5].

![Concern over government restrictions on civil liberties has fallen dramatically since July 2013](image4)

Comparing these opinions across political affiliations, the data indicates that while there is a general trend towards concern that policies do not go far enough to protect the country, the extent of this concern varies by age group and political affiliation. For instance, the table shows that conservative Republicans (71%), moderate and liberal Republicans (74%), and conservative and moderate Democrats (67%) all express greater concern that anti-terrorism policies have not gone far enough. By contrast, equal shares of liberal Democrats say their greater concern is that policies have gone too far in restricting average people’s civil liberties as say they worry more that these policies have not gone far enough to protect the country (41% each) [6].

This divergence in opinions highlights the nuanced nature of public sentiment regarding government anti-terrorism efforts, influenced by factors such as age, political affiliation, and historical context.

The public perception of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS has shown a complex evolution over time, marked by both negative assessments and increasing optimism about eventual success. According to text quote [7], views of the U.S. effort against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria have remained largely negative, with 58% saying the campaign is going not too well or not at all well. However, there has been an uptick in the belief that the U.S. and its allies will ultimately be successful, as indicated by text quote [9], where 66% now think the U.S. and its allies will succeed in their campaign against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria, up from 55% in July.

![{The bar chart shows the percentage of people who rated the U.S. military campaign against Islamic militants as "Not too/at all well" versus "Very/Fairly well" over several time periods.}](image1)

This trend is supported by text quote [1], which notes that current ratings of the U.S. military effort against ISIS remain negative, but there has been an uptick in the view that the U.S. and its allies will ultimately be successful. The data from image1 further illustrates this, showing that the percentage of people rating the campaign as "Not too/at all well" has fluctuated between 58% and 62% from October 2014 to December 2015, while the percentage rating it as "Very/Fairly well" has decreased from 34% to 35% during the same period.

Political affiliations play a significant role in shaping these perceptions. Text quote [2] highlights wide partisan divides in current assessments of the campaign against ISIS, with 45% of Democrats, 33% of independents, and 26% of Republicans saying the campaign is going at least fairly well. Text quote [10] further elaborates on these differences, noting that Conservative Republicans express more concern that the U.S. will not go far enough to stop ISIS, while Liberal Democrats express more concern that the U.S. will become too involved.

![{The bar chart shows the results of a survey about opinions on whether a policy will go far enough to stop militants, divided by age groups, political affiliation, and political leanings within parties.}](image2)

These differences are also reflected in the level of concern about various global issues, as shown in image3. While concerns about ISIS have increased significantly from August 2014 to December 2015, concerns about other issues such as global climate change and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict have either remained stable or decreased.

Overall, the public's perception of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS has evolved over time, with a general trend towards increased optimism about eventual success, despite ongoing negative assessments of the current state of the campaign. These perceptions are shaped by political affiliations, with significant differences in views between Republicans, Democrats, and Independents.

At that time, fully 47% wanted to cooperate less with America.

Conservative Americans and Germans on the right of the ideological spectrum are more likely than American liberals and Germans on the left to view Russia favorably. On the other hand, liberals and those on the left are more likely to favor the UN and EU than conservatives and those on the right. For all countries and organizations where those on the right and left did not see eye-to-eye, the divide is notably wider between Americans than it is between Germans.

Americans and Germans have distinct views on international organizations and economic powers, influenced by ideological and regional factors. For instance, when asked which country is the world’s leading economic power, Americans are more likely to name the U.S. (50%) compared to Germans, who favor China (53%) [7]. This divergence reflects broader ideological differences, with conservatives in both countries tending to view Russia more favorably, while liberals and those on the left favor the UN and EU [11].

![Half of Americans see their country as the top economic power; Germans more likely to name China](image1)

In terms of international organizations, Germans generally view the EU more positively than Americans. While roughly seven-in-ten Germans favor the union, only about half of Americans agree [10]. Similarly, favorable opinions of Russia are less widespread in both countries than positive views of the UN and EU. However, there is greater consensus on the UN and NATO, though Germans tend to think more highly of these organizations than Americans [10].

![The image appears to be a bar chart comparing various percentages related to the U.S., China, Japan, and the EU.](image1)

Regional differences also play a role. Germans living in former East Germany tend to view Russia more favorably and the EU less favorably than those in the former West. Specifically, 43% of East Germans have a favorable opinion of Russia, compared with one-third of those in the former West. Meanwhile, 71% of those in the former West favor the EU, while 59% of those in the former East agree [4].

![The image is a bar chart comparing the preferences of people from two regions, labeled "West" and "East," regarding the U.S., Russia, or Both (VOL).](image2)

Ideological divides further shape these perceptions. Conservatives in both countries are more likely to view Russia favorably, while liberals and those on the left are more likely to favor the UN and EU [11]. The divide between Americans and Germans on these issues is notably wider in the U.S. than in Germany [11].

![The image contains two bar charts comparing the preferences of Republican/Lean Republican and Democrat/Lean Democrat respondents towards certain countries.](image3)

These differences highlight the complex interplay of ideology, region, and historical context in shaping views of international organizations and economic powers among Americans and Germans.

The key differences between American and German opinions on military intervention and defense spending include a higher proportion of Americans supporting the use of military force compared to Germans, and a more divided stance on defense spending in Germany compared to the more unified view in the U.S.

The evolution of American and German opinions on defense spending can be seen through the data provided. In the U.S., there has been a notable shift in views regarding whether European allies should increase their defense spending. In 2017, 45% of Americans believed that their European allies should dedicate more resources to national defense. By 2019, this number had dropped to 35%, with 50% favoring keeping spending levels the same. This indicates a change in public opinion over the three-year period.

![Germans and Americans' opinions on defense spending](image1)

In contrast, Germans have shown more division on the issue. In 2017, about half of Germans were content with their country’s defense spending, while about a third felt it should be increased. By 2019, this division remained, with 40% supporting an increase, 41% favoring keeping it the same, and 15% supporting a decrease. This suggests that while there is a change in the percentage of people who support increasing defense spending, the overall trend is less clear-cut compared to the U.S.

Partisan differences also exist within each country. In the U.S., Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely than Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents to favor increased defense spending. However, the share among Republicans who think the U.S.’s European allies should increase their defense budgets has fallen by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019. There has also been a more modest decline in this view among Democrats.

![Partisan differences in U.S. opinion on defense spending](image2)

In Germany, partisan gaps also emerge. Supporters of the CDU/CSU are on balance in favor of defense spending increases. However, supporters of the Greens express more skepticism, with only 28% saying they want to raise defense spending. Members of the SPD fall in the middle, with 41% saying Germany should increase defense spending.

Nearly one-in-five think Chinese influence will grow, and about a third think its global standing will be about the same. [7] Few trust coronavirus information from Chinese government, believe China has handled outbreak well [3] Many also believe the current crisis will have a long-term impact on China’s global stature: 50% say China will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic. [1] A related question about America’s role in international affairs also shows strong differences along both partisan and ideological lines. Six-in-ten Americans say the U.S. should focus on its own problems and let other countries deal with the outbreak. [5] Age divides emerge on this question as well. American adults ages 65 and older are 16 percentage points more likely than those under 30 to say China will have less global influence after the crisis. [12] Whereas evaluations of both the United States’ and China’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak are quite partisan, this is less the case when it comes to the other four countries asked about in the survey. Democrats are somewhat more likely than Republicans to say Italy, South Korea and Germany have handled the outbreak well. But, in each of these instances, the difference is less than 10 percentage points. In the case of the UK, 54% of Republicans say the country has done an excellent or good job, compared with 45% of Democrats.

The data from 2013 to 2020 reveals stark partisan differences in views about the U.S. role in solving world problems and its influence after the coronavirus outbreak. ![The image is a line graph depicting the growing partisan divisions over the U.S.'s role in solving world problems from 2013 to 2020. It shows three lines representing different political affiliations:](image3) The red line (Rep/Lean Rep) starts at 52% in 2013, decreases to 37% by 2018, then rises again to 62% in 2020. The green line (Total) begins at 51% in 2013, decreases to 39% by 2018, and then increases to 42% in 2020. The blue line (Dem/Lean Dem) starts at 48% in 2013, falls to 21% by 2018, and then slightly increases to 26% in 2020. These trends indicate a growing divide between Republicans and Democrats on the U.S. role in global affairs.

Regarding the U.S. influence after the coronavirus outbreak, ![The image is a chart displaying survey data on opinions about the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak and related topics. It shows the responses broken down by political affiliation: Conservative/Moderate or Liberal Republicans (red dots) and Conservative/Moderate or Liberal Democrats (blue dots).](image6) Liberal Democrats are significantly more likely than conservative Republicans to believe the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs after the outbreak. Specifically, 56% of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. will have less influence, compared to only 8% of conservative Republicans. This reflects a clear partisan gap in perceptions of U.S. global influence post-pandemic.

[1] The Pew Research Center indicates that $60\%$ of Americans believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems and let other countries handle their own, while $39\%$ think the U.S. should help others. This reflects a general view that the U.S. may not be the primary responder in global issues. ![Partisan divisions over the U.S.'s role in solving world problems](image1)

[11] There are significant partisan differences over how much the U.S. can learn from the international response. While $60\%$ of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents say the U.S. can learn a great deal, just $28\%$ of Republicans and Republican leaners share that view. ![Partisan differences in learning from international response](image5)

[5] Even though the belief that the U.S. can learn at least a fair amount from the rest of the world is widely shared across the political spectrum, those on the left are much more likely to think the country can learn a great deal from other nations: $67\%$ of liberal Democrats hold this view, compared with only $25\%$ of conservative Republicans. ![Learning from other nations](image5)

[12] More than eight-in-ten Americans say the U.S. can learn either a great deal or a fair amount from other countries about ways to slow the spread of the coronavirus. By comparison, fewer than two-in-ten say the U.S. can learn not too much or nothing at all from other countries. ![Learning from other countries](image2)

[9] Fully $64\%$ of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. should help other countries. This is significantly higher than the $44\%$ registered among moderate and conservative Democrats, and nearly triple the shares of moderate and liberal Republicans and conservative Republicans who hold this view. ![Helping other countries](image5)

[3] Liberal Democrats stand apart for their bleak assessment of how the pandemic will affect America’s standing on the global stage: $56\%$ believe the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs, 20 percentage points higher than the share of moderate and conservative Democrats who say this (just $15\%$ of moderate and liberal Republicans and $8\%$ of conservative Republicans say the U.S. will have less influence). ![U.S. influence in global affairs](image5)

[10] The question of whether the U.S. should deal with its own problems or help other countries is deeply divided along political and educational lines. According to the text, **60%** of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations about slowing the spread of the coronavirus, while only **28%** of Republicans and Republican leaners share this view. This partisan divide is reflected in the image, which shows a stark contrast between **Dem/Lean Dem** (60% a great deal) and **Rep/Lean Rep** (28% a great deal) in terms of how much the U.S. can learn from other countries [image2].

![How much the U.S. can learn from other countries](image2)

The image also highlights that **postgraduates** are more likely to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other countries compared to those with lower levels of education. For instance, **56%** of postgraduates say the U.S. can learn a great deal, whereas only **41%** of those with a high school degree or less hold this view [image2].

![Educational attainment and learning from other countries](image2)

In terms of political affiliation, **Democrats** are more supportive of helping other countries, with **64%** of liberal Democrats believing the U.S. should help other countries, compared to **44%** of conservative and moderate Democrats. This is further illustrated in the image, which shows a clear divide between **Dem/Lean Dem** and **Rep/Lean Rep** in their views on how much the U.S. can learn from other countries [image2].

![Political affiliation and learning from other countries](image2)

Overall, the data suggests that **higher education levels** and **Democratic political affiliation** are associated with a greater belief that the U.S. can learn from other countries, while **lower education levels** and **Republican political affiliation** are linked to a more limited view of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other nations.

The perception of the U.S. role in solving world problems varies significantly by political affiliation, as shown in the data. According to [2], a majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. does too much, while only 8% think it does too little. In contrast, a plurality of Democrats (48%) believe the U.S. does too little, with 26% each thinking it does the right amount or too much. This reflects a clear partisan divide in views on America's global involvement.

![The image shows the percentage of people who believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems or let others manage their own as best they can.](image1)

Over time, these perceptions have evolved. The data from [6] and [7] indicate that more educated Americans are more critical of how the U.S. has handled global issues, but there is also a significant divide along party lines. For instance, [8] highlights that opinions on the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak are most divided along party lines, with 73% of Democrats being critical compared to 71% of Republicans praising the handling.

Looking at historical data, [5] notes that the partisan divide in these views was less pronounced in previous years. However, recent trends show a growing gap. [10] indicates that in 2013, the partisan gap was more modest, but by the time of the survey, the divide had widened.

![This image provides a detailed breakdown of survey responses across different demographic groups regarding their level of agreement with various statements.](image2)

The changes in perceptions over time are also evident in the line graphs. [6] and [7] show that from 2013 to 2020, the percentage of people who thought the U.S. did too much increased, while those who thought it did too little decreased. This trend is particularly pronounced among Republicans, as seen in [10].

![This image displays the percentage of people who evaluated the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak as "Only fair/poor" or "Good/excellent" across different demographic groups.](image3)

Overall, the data reveals a consistent pattern of differing views between Republicans and Democrats regarding the U.S. role in global affairs, with these differences becoming more pronounced over time.

The views on U.S. global engagement and domestic issues differ significantly by political affiliation and educational attainment, as illustrated by various survey data.

![{The image shows the percentage of people who believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems or help other countries.}](image7)

According to the data, Republicans are more likely to believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems, with 60% of Republicans saying this, compared to 40% who think the U.S. should help other countries. Among Democrats, 46% believe the U.S. should help other countries, while 53% think it should deal with its own problems. This is reflected in the image, where the percentage of Republicans who believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems is higher than that of Democrats [7].

Education also plays a role in these views. Postgraduates are more supportive of helping other nations deal with their problems, with 60% saying the U.S. should help other countries, while college graduates are evenly split. Those with some college experience and those with no more than a high school diploma are more likely to believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems [3].

These differences are further highlighted in the image, which shows the percentage of people from different educational backgrounds who believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems or help other countries [3]. The data indicates that higher education levels are associated with a greater willingness to help other nations, while lower education levels are more inclined to focus on domestic issues.

The views on the impact of trade policies with China and the preference for getting tougher versus building stronger relationships vary significantly across different political affiliations in the U.S. According to the data, Republicans, especially conservative Republicans, are more likely to believe that tariffs on Chinese goods have been good for the U.S. [5]. This is reflected in the bar chart (image1), where conservative Republicans (Rep/Lean Rep - Conserv) show a higher percentage (61%) believing the tariffs were good for the U.S., compared to moderate/liberal Republicans (Rep/Lean Rep - Mod/Lib) who are more divided. ![Bad for U.S.](image1) 

On the other hand, Democrats, particularly liberal Democrats, are more likely to view the tariffs as bad for the U.S. [5]. This is evident in image1, where liberal Democrats (Dem/Lean Dem - Liberal) have a high percentage (63%) believing the tariffs were bad for the U.S. The chart also shows that among Democrats, those who identify as liberal are the most likely to emphasize human rights over economic dealings in U.S.-China relations [10]. 

When it comes to preferences for trade policies with China, the data indicates that a majority of Republicans prefer getting tougher with China, with 72% of Republican-leaning independents and 81% of conservative Republicans favoring a tougher stance [2]. This is supported by image5, which shows that Republican/Lean Republican voters are more inclined to support a "Get tougher" approach, with 72% preferring this over building a strong relationship. ![Get tougher](image5)

In contrast, Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents are more likely to prefer building stronger relationships with China [2]. This is also reflected in image5, where Democrats/Lean Democrats show a preference for building a strong relationship, with 60% supporting this approach. 

The differences in opinions are also evident in the bar chart (image3), which compares perceptions of China and the U.S. doing a "bad job" or a "good job." For China, 54% of respondents believe it is doing a "bad job," while for the U.S., 58% think it is doing a "bad job." This suggests a general perception of a precarious economic relationship between the two nations [11]. 

Overall, the data shows that political affiliations significantly influence views on the impact of trade policies with China and the preferred approach to these policies. Republicans tend to favor a tougher stance, while Democrats prefer building stronger relationships.

The perspectives of different political affiliations on the impacts of tariffs and international students in the U.S. show significant differences. Regarding international students, [11] indicates that eight-in-ten Americans say it is good for U.S. colleges and universities to accept international students, while just 19% think the opposite. However, [8] shows that while the U.S. public generally welcomes international students, people are more divided when it comes specifically to Chinese students. A majority of Americans (55%) support limiting Chinese students, whereas 43% oppose such limitations.

In terms of tariffs, [3] highlights that Republicans see tariffs on Chinese and other foreign goods as having a positive effect for the U.S., while Democrats disagree. [4] further explains that about half of Republicans say increased tariffs on Chinese and other foreign products were good for the U.S., with conservative Republicans showing stronger support. In contrast, Democrats most often say the tariffs were bad for the U.S. [6] also notes that more Americans believe the tariffs were ultimately bad for the U.S. than good, with 44% thinking they were bad and 30% thinking they were good.

![image2](image2)  
![image3](image3)  

These charts illustrate the partisan divide on both issues, with Republicans generally supporting tariffs and welcoming international students, while Democrats tend to oppose tariffs and have a more nuanced view on international students.

The opinions on limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities vary significantly across age groups and political affiliations, as well as relate to confidence in the Chinese leadership. For instance, older Americans are more likely to express concern about China-related issues, with 58% of those aged 50 and older stating that limiting China’s power and influence should be a top priority, compared to 39% of those under 50 [6]. This suggests that age plays a role in shaping views on China.

Furthermore, Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor limitations on the number of Chinese students attending U.S. colleges or universities [4]. This aligns with the broader trend where Republicans are significantly more likely to view China as an enemy rather than a competitor or partner [4]. 

![Confidence in Chinese Leadership](image6)  
This image shows levels of confidence in a certain topic, divided by different demographic groups. The categories measured are "No confidence at all," "Not too much confidence," "Some confidence," and "A lot of confidence." It highlights that older groups (65+) have the highest "no confidence," while Democrats/Lean Dem show more confidence, with 16% having "some confidence."

Additionally, there is a notable difference in confidence in the Chinese president across demographics. For example, 53% of those 65 and older say they have no confidence at all in Xi, compared to only 35% of those 18 to 29 [10]. This indicates that age is a factor in confidence in Chinese leadership.

![Public Opinion on Limiting Chinese Students](image4)  
This image displays survey results on opinions toward an unspecified topic, categorized by various demographics in the U.S. It shows that overall, 43% oppose and 55% support limiting Chinese students. By race, White respondents have the highest "no confidence" at 50%, while blacks have more "some confidence" and "a lot of confidence." By age group, older groups (65+) have the highest "no confidence," and younger groups (18-29) have the highest "oppose" rate. By political affiliation, Republicans/Lean Republican have more no confidence, while Democrats/Lean Democrat show more confidence.

In summary, older Americans and Republicans are more likely to support limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities and have less confidence in the Chinese leadership.

The financial optimism among different Hispanic subgroups has shown significant improvement from 2008 to 2015, with the overall percentage of Latinos expecting their family’s financial situation to improve increasing by 14 percentage points, reaching 81% in 2015. This is a notable increase compared to the general population, which saw a 6 percentage point rise to 61% during the same period [10]. 

![{The bar chart shows the increase in financial optimism among Hispanics compared to the general public.}] (image6)

Among various subgroups, the gains in optimism have been particularly pronounced. For instance, Latino men showed an 18-point increase, while Latina women experienced an 11-point increase in their financial optimism [3]. The data also reveals that all Latino subgroups have become more optimistic about their financial future since 2011, with the share of Latinos expecting their finances to improve “a lot” or “some” rising from 67% in 2008 to 81% in 2015 [12]. 

![{The bar chart compares the percentage of favorable opinions between two groups, labeled "Hispanic" and "General public."}] (image5)

Looking at specific demographics, the most significant increases were observed among younger age groups, such as those aged 18-29, who saw a 27 percentage point rise in their optimism [7]. Additionally, Latinos with higher education levels, including those with some college education, showed a 20 percentage point increase in optimism, outpacing those with less education [9]. 

![{The bar chart compares the percentage of various demographic groups' support or approval for a particular issue or candidate in the years 2008 and 2015.}] (image7)

In contrast, older Latinos, while still showing overall optimism, were less upbeat about their short-term economic future compared to younger and middle-aged Hispanics [2]. However, even among older Latinos, there was a substantial increase in optimism, with 81% expecting their financial situation to improve in 2015 [4]. 

Overall, the financial optimism among Hispanic subgroups has grown significantly faster than that of the general population, highlighting a broader trend of economic recovery and improved outlook among Latinos.

The financial expectations of Hispanics for their children are significantly influenced by both their current financial situations and educational levels. According to text quote [1], about 72% of Hispanic adults expect their children will be better off financially than they themselves are, while 16% expect their children’s financial situation will be about the same as theirs. This optimism is echoed in text quote [5], which states that most Hispanics are confident their finances will improve in the next year and also see a bright financial future for their children.

However, text quote [8] highlights that views differ by age, with older Latinos more pessimistic about their children’s financial futures than younger Latinos. Among those ages 65 and older, 52% say their children will be better off than themselves, whereas 75% of Latinos ages 18 to 29 have similar expectations. This suggests that younger Hispanics tend to be more optimistic about their children's financial futures.

Text quote [10] further illustrates that there are differences by educational attainment among Latinos. Latino high school graduates are more optimistic than those with some college experience or more, with 79% predicting that their children will be better off financially. This indicates that higher education levels correlate with greater optimism regarding children's financial futures.

![image3](image3)  
This image shows the perceived economic well-being of different Hispanic groups, highlighting that a significant proportion of surveyed Hispanics believe they are economically better off than before, with variations across different demographics. For instance, 72% of all Hispanics expect their children will be better off financially than they themselves are, while 75% of foreign-born Hispanics have similar expectations.

In terms of current financial situations, text quote [4] indicates that Hispanics with a positive view of their current financial situation are significantly more likely than those who rate their economic circumstances as only fair or poor to say their family’s finances will improve over the next 12 months. This aligns with text quote [12], which notes that optimism about their family’s future economic prospects has risen faster among Latinos than in the population as a whole.

In summary, current financial situations and educational levels play a crucial role in shaping the financial expectations of Hispanics for their children. Those with more optimistic current financial situations and higher educational attainment tend to have higher expectations for their children's financial futures.

From 2000 to 2015, Latinos have shown a generally positive trend in their financial perceptions and unemployment rates. According to the data, while there was a period of decline during the recession (highlighted in grey in image4), the percentage of Latinos who expect their family's finances to improve "a lot" or "some" increased from 31% in 2004 to 81% in 2015, outpacing the general public's increase from 70% to 61% during the same period. ![Hispanic and General Public Financial Expectations](image4)

![Latino Unemployment Trends](image7) shows that the Latino unemployment rate has declined from 5.8% in 2000 to 6.4% in 2015, though it remains above its 2006 low of 5%. Despite this improvement, the rate is still higher than that of non-Hispanic workers in 2015.

The economic impact of the Latino community has grown significantly, contributing to job growth and increasing purchasing power. However, median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, with a median income of $42,491 in 2014, which is lower than the median income for all U.S. households at $53,700. The poverty rate for Hispanics in 2014 was 23.6%, which is higher than the rate for all U.S. households at 14.8%. ![Income and Poverty Rates](image2)

Despite these challenges, there is a growing sense of optimism among Latinos regarding their financial future. About seven-in-ten Hispanic adults expect their children will be better off financially than they themselves are, reflecting a belief in economic upward mobility. ![Financial Upward Mobility](image11)

The trends in unemployment rates and economic perceptions between Hispanic and non-Hispanic populations reveal a complex picture. According to the data, the U.S. Latino unemployment rate is declining but remains above its 2006 low [3]. In contrast, non-Hispanic unemployment rates have generally shown a more consistent decline, with rates dropping from 3.8% in 2000 to 4.8% in 2015 [8]. This indicates that while both groups have seen improvements, Hispanics still face higher unemployment rates compared to non-Hispanics.

![Hispanic and Non-Hispanic Unemployment Rates](image8)

Economic perceptions among Hispanics are more positive than those of the general population. For instance, in 2015, 72% of Latinos said they expect their children to be better off financially than they themselves are now [7], whereas the general public's perception is lower. Additionally, 35% of Hispanics rated economic conditions as good or excellent in 2015, compared to 25% of whites [5]. This suggests a more optimistic outlook among Hispanics despite economic challenges.

![Perceptions of Economic Well-being](image1)

However, when it comes to actual economic indicators, there are significant disparities. The median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, remaining at $42,491 in 2014, which is lower than the median income for all U.S. households at $53,700 [2]. Furthermore, the poverty rate for Hispanic households was 23.6% in 2014, significantly higher than the 14.8% for all U.S. households [2]. Wealth disparities are even more pronounced, with Hispanic households experiencing the largest percentage decline in net worth through 2009, and their net worth continuing to fall after the recession [2].

![Income and Poverty Rate Comparison](image2)

These disparities highlight the ongoing challenges faced by Hispanic communities, even as there is a growing economic footprint and increasing confidence among Latinos. Despite these challenges, the data shows a mixed economic picture for the Hispanic community, with some improvements in employment and perceptions of future financial well-being, but persistent issues with income and wealth.

![Hispanic and General Public Perceptions of Economic Well-being](image1) [1]  
The pie chart illustrates how people feel about their well-being compared to a prior period, with 72% feeling "better off," 16% "about the same," and 5% "less well off." This suggests a generally positive trend in economic perceptions.

![Trends in Economic Views Over Time](image2) [2]  
The line graph shows that while both the general public and Hispanic groups experienced a decline during the recession (2008-2010), Hispanic views improved more significantly over time, reaching 40% in 2015 compared to 31% in 2004. The general public's percentage dropped from 51% in 2004 to 38% in 2011, then increased to 43% by 2015.

![Comparative Attitudes of Hispanics and the General Public](image3) [3]  
The line graph indicates that Hispanic opinions have remained generally higher and increased more than the general public's over the years, with Hispanic percentages at 76%, 67%, 73%, and 81% in 2004, 2008, 2011, and 2015 respectively, compared to the general public's 70%, 56%, 58%, and 61%.

The three line graphs show that Hispanic households have lower median income ($42,500 in 2014) compared to all U.S. households ($53,700), a higher poverty rate (23.6% in 2014 vs. 14.8% for all U.S. households), and lower median wealth ($13,700 in 2013 vs. $81,400 for all U.S. households).

![Support for Various Issues Among Different Demographic Groups](image7) [6]  
The bar chart shows a general increase in support among all groups from 2008 to 2015, with notable increases among Latinos, particularly U.S.-born and foreign-born individuals.

![Perceptions of Family Income Relative to Cost of Living](image8) [7]  
The bar chart indicates that in both 2014 and 2015, a significant percentage of Hispanic adults felt their income was falling behind the cost of living, with 53% in 2015, compared to 59% for White adults and 55% for Black adults in 2014.

Despite growing confidence and a larger economic footprint, federal government data shows a mixed economic picture for the Hispanic community recently. Hispanic unemployment rates have declined but remain above their 2006 low, median household income has stagnated, the poverty rate remains high, and wealth has seen a significant decline.

[10] Four-in-ten Latinos say their personal finances are in “excellent” or “good” shape, a 17 percentage point increase since 2008, when only 23% made a similarly positive assessment of their finances (the Great Recession began in December 2007). By contrast, the share of all Americans who have a similarly positive view of their finances remained essentially flat during the same seven-year period (41% in 2008 vs. 43% in 2015).

![{The pie chart shows a significant increase in positive perceptions of financial well-being among Latinos compared to the general public.}] (image2)

[6] These differences by age are the exception, not the rule, as similar-sized gains are recorded among most other demographic subgroups. For example, ratings of personal finances rose by 17 percentage points among U.S.-born Hispanics and by 18 points among those born in another country. Positive views of economic well-being rose by 16 percentage points among Latino men and by 18 points among Latina women. These rosy assessments also increased by double digits among those with less than a high school education (+12 points) and high school graduates (+16 points) as well as those who had attended college (+17 points).

![{The bar chart compares the percentage of support or approval for a particular issue or candidate among different demographic groups in 2008 and 2015.}] (image6)

[11] In 2015, about half (53%) of Latinos said their family income is not keeping up with the cost of living. Meanwhile, 37% said their income is staying about even with the cost of living, and 10% said it is going up faster than the cost of living. In 2015, blacks and whites held similar views as Hispanics on this issue.

![{The bar chart compares the perceptions of family income relative to the cost of living among Hispanic, White, and Black adults in 2014 and 2015.}] (image1)

[4] Between 2014 and 2015, Hispanic views of family income in relation to the cost of living were unchanged—about half of all Hispanic adults in both years said they were falling behind financially, as was true for the U.S. public as a whole.

[8] An analysis of 2008 and 2015 survey data finds that Latino perceptions of their economic well-being have increased among most major Latino demographic subgroups.

[7] Looking back to before the recession reveals another striking difference between Hispanic economic perceptions and those of the U.S. population as a whole. Latino views of their financial situation are more positive now than they were in 2004, when roughly a third (31%) rated their financial condition as excellent or good. By contrast, the public’s view of its finances is lower now than in 2004, when about half (51%) had a positive view.
